purpose: Solver-approximation for river behavior retuned using theory/postflop/examples/solver_truth_docs/river_matrix.MD. Values are heuristic guidance (not solver exports).

meta.notes: Blank rivers preserve turn equities and encourage river polarization (clear value/bluff separation). When betting, larger sizing (≈66–75% or overbet) is common; small block bets appear with marginal value / pot-control incentives.

Overcard rivers are narrative-heavy and often polarizing. When the overcard favors IP's range composition, larger sizing (≈75%+ or overbet) becomes common; otherwise IP checks more and OOP may gain leading/probing incentives.

pairing_river.label: River Pairs the Board (turn pairs → river pairs)

meta.notes: Pairing rivers increase showdown-value density and reduce incentives to run large bluffs. Small block bets (≈20–33%) and cautious value thresholds are common; large sizing is reserved for very strong hands.

Board-pairing rivers that complete full houses create extreme polarity: very strong value hands and occasional blocker-driven bluffs. Large bets and overbets are common; medium-strength hands often check.

Straight-completing rivers shift nut advantage and often compress medium holdings into bluff-catchers. Small block bets are common for thin value / pot-control; larger sizing appears when a player has clearer nut advantage.

Flush-completing rivers are highly polar. The flush-holder can value bet large; the non-flush player often checks or uses small blocks. Blockers (nut flush blocker) strongly influence bluff selection.

double_paired_river.label: River Creates a Double-Paired Board (two different pairs on board)

meta.notes: Double-paired rivers are showdown-heavy and reduce bluff incentives. Small sizing (block/value) and checks dominate; raises are typically value and bluffs require exceptional blockers.

counterfeited_river.label: Counterfeit / River Reduces Hand Strength (low card pairing an overcard)

meta.notes: Counterfeits reduce the strength of many one-pair hands and increase checking. When betting, small sizing is common; bluffing relies heavily on blockers and not blocking opponent's folding range.

dynamic_to_static_transition.label: Dynamic Flop/Turn → Static River (many draws miss and river is a brick)

examples: T♥9♦8♣ → 2♠ (river brick after many draws missed)
meta.notes: When draws miss and the river is a brick, ranges re-polarize. IP often uses larger sizing to target bluff-catchers; bluffing frequency tends to be lower and more blocker-driven.

static_to_polarizing_transition.label: Static Flop/Turn → Polarizing River (river creates polarized textures)

meta.notes: When a previously static runout becomes polarizing on the river (new straights/flushes/pairs appear), both ranges polarize and overbets become more common. Bluff selection should emphasize nut blockers.

defaults.notes: If classification fails, fall back to these conservative values. Values are heuristic guidance (not solver exports) retuned from solver-truth documentation.

notes.usage: Numeric fields are provided for sampling by the SpotGenerator; qualitative fields (bet_freq_qual) are for explanation text and UI. Map sizingRefs to exact BB amounts using pot math and rounding rules. Keep 'meta.notes' for human/LLM explanation only; do not use meta.notes to make decisions.
